docs.snippet: Darcy Ribeiro, an anthropologist who unlocked the cultural riches of Brazil's Indians for the rest of his country, died at a hospital in Brasilia on Monday. He was 74.    The cause was cancer, according to a report from the Sarah Kubitschek Hospital.
docs.lead_paragraph: Darcy Ribeiro, an anthropologist who unlocked the cultural riches of Brazil's Indians for the rest of his country, died at a hospital in Brasilia on Monday. He was 74. The cause was cancer, according to a report from the Sarah Kubitschek Hospital.
docs.abstract: Darcy Ribeiro, anthropologist who was expert on Brazilian Indian culture, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline.main: Darcy Ribeiro, 74, Expert On Brazilian Indian Culture

docs.snippet: If you're hungry for beef and plenty of it, you may be looking for a place like 18 de Julio, a Uruguayan grill in Jackson Heights, Queens, a neighborhood that is home to many South American grills.    Uruguay, like its neighbor Argentina, is a...
docs.lead_paragraph: If you're hungry for beef and plenty of it, you may be looking for a place like 18 de Julio, a Uruguayan grill in Jackson Heights, Queens, a neighborhood that is home to many South American grills. Uruguay, like its neighbor Argentina, is a carnivore's paradise. At 18 de Julio, named for the date that Uruguay celebrates its constitution, the focus is on beef -- more precisely, great big slabs of beef, served unadorned, still sizzling from the grill.
docs.abstract: Eric Asimov $25 and Under review of 18 de Julio, Uruguayan grill in Jackson Heights (S)

docs.snippet: The BellSouth Corporation is in talks to buy almost half of the telephone company of Nicaragua for about $20 million. An investment in Nicacel would be BellSouth's seventh in Latin America, where the Atlanta-based Baby Bell would like to expand a...
docs.lead_paragraph: The BellSouth Corporation is in talks to buy almost half of the telephone company of Nicaragua for about $20 million. An investment in Nicacel would be BellSouth's seventh in Latin America, where the Atlanta-based Baby Bell would like to expand a strategy of selling wireless telephones. Just 2 percent of Nicaraguans own phones. BellSouth sees wireless communications as a way for underdeveloped countries to leapfrog past the need the build costly wired systems. The company, which last year had almost $1 billion in revenue from its international cellular service, currently has investments in Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Venezuela, Panama and Peru.
docs.abstract: BellSouth Corp is in talks to buy almost half of Nicacel, telephone company of Nicaragua, for about $20 million; investment in Nicacel would be BellSouth's seventh in Latin America (S)

docs.snippet: We are stealing down the Rio Negro, in southwestern Brazil, the throttle on low. At the water's edge the protruding eyes of caimans float just above the surface. Glistening like marbles, they duck underwater in a soundless vertical drop as we pass...
docs.lead_paragraph: We are stealing down the Rio Negro, in southwestern Brazil, the throttle on low. At the water's edge the protruding eyes of caimans float just above the surface. Glistening like marbles, they duck underwater in a soundless vertical drop as we pass their field of vision. There is something hypnotic and frightening about the utter completeness of their disappearance, leaving just a momentary bubble or two behind. The image spreads a chilling, primordial unease in our little fishing boat, a reminder of nature's fancy for the perfect crime. Our metal spinner trails behind us, a phony fish flashing sunlight in the water; we hope it will trick dinner, a pintado or golden dorado, into our boat.
docs.abstract: Diana Jean Schemo article on journey through Pantanal, vast wetlands stretching over Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay, and occupying more than 50,000 square miles in two Brazilian states; much of region is accessible only by horseback, boat or plane during wet season; area alongside highway is national park land, but 90 percent of Pantanal is privately owned, used mostly for ranching; photos; map (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

headline.main: A Brazilian Wetland, Burgeoning With Wildlife

docs.snippet: In Little Havana's Maximo Gomez Park, named after the 19th-century Cuban patriot, the boisterous crowd of regulars, all in their 60's, 70's and 80's, interrupt their domino game only to go get a cortadito, Cuban coffee. They call one another...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Little Havana's Maximo Gomez Park, named after the 19th-century Cuban patriot, the boisterous crowd of regulars, all in their 60's, 70's and 80's, interrupt their domino game only to go get a cortadito, Cuban coffee. They call one another ''brother'' or ''partner'' in Spanish, trade stories about past adventures and talk politics but rarely argue. They are all staunchly anti-Castro. The scene at Domino Park, as it is more commonly known, is quintessential Hispanic Miami, one of the images that has defined this city, where Cuban immigrants have dominated in numbers and clout since the 1980's.
docs.abstract: New immigration and higher birth rates among other Hispanic groups have dramatically altered composition of Hispanic mix over last two decades in Miami, where Cuban-Americans are still predominant Hispanic group; have made area's economy heavily dependent on international trade, given politicians another group to cater to and maintained Spanish as well-entrenched language, with different accents; photos (L)4

headline.main: Other Hispanic Groups Growing in Miami
headline.kicker: Within Little Havana, A Change in Accents

docs.snippet: A German citizen suspected of having links to Basque terrorists has surrendered to the police in Wiesbaden, Germany, ending a manhunt that began in Madrid on Saturday, Spanish officials said today.    The arrest of the German citizen, Fritz Gary...
docs.lead_paragraph: A German citizen suspected of having links to Basque terrorists has surrendered to the police in Wiesbaden, Germany, ending a manhunt that began in Madrid on Saturday, Spanish officials said today. The arrest of the German citizen, Fritz Gary Siemund, points to wider international support for the Basque separatists, who have long had close links with sympathizers in France. These ties greatly concern the Spanish authorities, who have been trying to cut off the separatists' support in Mexico, Uruguay and elsewhere in Latin America. Authorities are still looking for another German who is believed to be linked to the rebels, who are fighting for an independent Basque homeland in northern Spain.
docs.abstract: Fritz Gary Siemund, German suspected of having links to Basque terrorists, surrenders to German police, ending manhunt that began after bomb exploded accidentally in his Madrid apartment; second man is sought; arrest points to wider international support for Basque separatists (S)

headline.main: Germany Arrests Suspect Linked to Basque Group

docs.lead_paragraph: DEC. 17, 1996 -- Tupac Amaru rebels infiltrate residence of Japanese Ambassador during a cocktail party, taking an estimated 600 hostages, including Peruvian officials and foreign ambassadors. Within hours, they release hundreds of guests. DEC. 18 -- Rebels demand release of jailed comrades and threaten to start killing hostages.
docs.abstract: Chronology of events in Peruvian hostage crisis; photo (M)

headline.main: Peru Held Hostage: Four Months of Torment Ends Abruptly

docs.abstract: Auto executives around the world have concluded that Brazil and Argentina, which taken together make up 80 percent of South America's auto sales, represent even more lucrative market than Southeast Asia or Eastern Europe; American, European and Japanese car makers are pouring total of $18 billion into new South American factories, convinced that recent double-digit sales growth will continue; main reason for auto boom has been resurgence of economic growth in Brazil and Argentina; production plans for major automakers, including Ford Motor and Chrysler Corp, discussed; table; graph; photos (L)

headline.main: Hot Markets Are Producing Cars For Domestic Buyers and Export
headline.kicker: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: In South America, Auto Makers See One Big Showroom

docs.snippet: With their top two strikers away for World Cup duty, the MetroStars will have two new faces on their attack when they play the Columbus Crew tomorrow night at Giants Stadium.    Anthony De Avila and Giovanni Savarese have joined their national teams...
docs.lead_paragraph: With their top two strikers away for World Cup duty, the MetroStars will have two new faces on their attack when they play the Columbus Crew tomorrow night at Giants Stadium. Anthony De Avila and Giovanni Savarese have joined their national teams from Colombia and Venezuela, respectively, and will miss the game against Columbus.
docs.abstract: Anthony De Avila and Giovanni Savarese of MetroStars have joined their national teams from Colombia and Venezuela for World Cup, and will miss MetroStars upcoming game against Columbus Crew (M)

headline.main: MetroStars to Rely on Substitute Strikers

docs.snippet: TRACK AND FIELD  Keino Lifts Arizona in Relay       As long as Bob Keino is anchoring, Arizona relay teams are never out of a race. Getting the baton in sixth place, Keino brought Arizona from 40 meters back on the final carry to give the Wildcats a...
docs.lead_paragraph: TRACK AND FIELD Keino Lifts Arizona in Relay As long as Bob Keino is anchoring, Arizona relay teams are never out of a race. Getting the baton in sixth place, Keino brought Arizona from 40 meters back on the final carry to give the Wildcats a victory in the 6,400-meter relay yesterday at the Drake Relays in Des Moines. Running in ideal 60-degree weather, the son of the legendary distance star Kip Keino churned out a 1,600-meter leg in 3 minutes 59.6 seconds as Arizona won a distance relay at Drake for the third consecutive year. Arizona finished in 16:29.14 to beat Notre Dame, which ran 16:31.20. (AP)
docs.abstract: University of Arizona wins 6,400-meter relay at Drake Relays in Des Moines (S)
